questions.text: Which of the following is not part of Virchow’s triad?
questions.solution:
Thrombus formation is not included in Virchow’s triad.

Virchow’s triad refers to three primary influences that predispose to thrombus formation:

  • Endothelial injury
  • Stasis or low turbulence of blood flow
  • Blood hypercoagulability

questions.text: Which of the following patients are not at an increased risk for developing deep vein thrombosis?

choices.text: Woman on high dose oestrogen therapy for menopausal symptoms
Middle aged man with polycythemia vera
Teenager who has sustained major trauma in an accident

questions.solution:
Nephritic syndrome is not associated with an increased risk of DVT. Nephrotic syndrome is associated with an increased risk of developing deep vein thrombosis.

Deep vein thrombosis is the presence or formation of a thrombus is present in the deep venous system, usually in the deep veins lower limbs.

Related Pearl: Risk Factors for Venous Thromboembolism

The risk factors for venous thromboembolism (pulmonary embolism and DVT) are as follows:

  • Major trauma like spinal cord injury or fracture of lower limb
  • Surgery like hip or knee replacement
  • Hospitalization for heart failure or atrial fibrillation/flutter within last 3 months
  • Myocardial infarction within last 3 months
  • Previous venous thromboembolism
  • Infections and inflammatory bowel disease
  • Autoimmune diseases:
    • Antiphospholipid antibody (APLA)
    • SLE
  • Inherited thrombophilias:
    • Factor V leiden mutation
    • Deficiency of antithrombin III
    • Deficiency of protein C or protein S
  • Hypercoagulable states:
    • Pregnancy and postpartum period
    • COPD
    • Nephrotic syndrome
    • Polycythemia vera
    • Malignancies
  • Iatrogenic:
    • OCPs
    • Hormone replacement therapy
    • Chemotherapeutic drugs
    • Insertion of central venous lines
  • Varicose veins
  • Prolonged car or air travel.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding deep vein thrombosis (DVT)?

choices.text: Most common clinical presentation is pain and tenderness in calf
Some cases may directly present as pulmonary thromboembolism

questions.solution:
Most cases of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) are unilateral. It is bilateral in only 30% of the individuals.

DVT refers to thrombosis of the deep venous system.

Caused by:

  • Postoperative thrombosis (most common cause)
  • Oral contraceptive pills (OCPs)
  • After childbirth
  • Immobility 

Sites:

  • Pelvic veins—common
  • Leg veins—common in femoral and popliteal veins (common on the left side).

Fever is the earliest symptom, which is also most commonly accompanied by pain and tenderness in the calf and thigh (option C).

The following signs could be elicited:

  • Positive Homan's sign: Resistance of calf muscles on passive foreceful dorsiflexion of the foot.
  • Mose's sign: Gentle squeezing of the lower part of the calf from side to side is painful.
  • Neuhof's sign: Thickening and deep tenderness seen on deep palpation of the calf muscles.

Sometimes, the thrombus may get dislodged and present as pulmonary thromboembolism (option D) with features of dyspnoea, tachypnoea, and chest pain.

Clinical features are unreliable for making a definitive diagnosis (option A), and a venous Doppler is the best modality for confirming DVT. It reveals a non-compressible dilated vein. The likelihood of pulmonary embolism can be predicted using modified Wells criteria.

Patients with DVT should be immediately started with subcutaneous low molecular weight heparin (LMWH). If contraindicated due to renal insufficiency or thrombocytopenia-related conditions, they should be started on fondaparinux (indirect factor Xa inhibitor) or bivalirudin (direct thrombin inhibitor). Anticoagulants should be administered for a minimum period of 3 months. Vena cava filters are used in patients with bleeding risks (like hemophilia).

Related Pearl: Risk Factors for Venous Thromboembolism

The risk factors for venous thromboembolism (pulmonary embolism and DVT) are as follows:

  • Major trauma like spinal cord injury or fracture of lower limb
  • Surgery like hip or knee replacement
  • Hospitalization for heart failure or atrial fibrillation/flutter within last 3 months
  • Myocardial infarction within last 3 months
  • Previous venous thromboembolism
  • Infections and inflammatory bowel disease
  • Autoimmune diseases:
    • Antiphospholipid antibody (APLA)
    • SLE
  • Inherited thrombophilias:
    • Factor V leiden mutation
    • Deficiency of antithrombin III
    • Deficiency of protein C or protein S
  • Hypercoagulable states:
    • Pregnancy and postpartum period
    • COPD
    • Nephrotic syndrome
    • Polycythemia vera
    • Malignancies
  • Iatrogenic:
    • OCPs
    • Hormone replacement therapy
    • Chemotherapeutic drugs
    • Insertion of central venous lines
  • Varicose veins
  • Prolonged car or air travel.

Related Pearl: Prophylaxis for DVT

Mechanical prophylaxis
Early ambulation

Acts by activating the calf pump mechanism
Pneumatic compression stocking

Prevents stasis by periodically compressing the calves
Pharmacological prophylaxis

Low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) - Enoxaparin

Fondaparinux

 Prevent thrombus formation by inhibiting factor Xa

Apixaban

Rivaroxaban 

  Oral factor Xa inhibitors

Unfractionated heparin (UFH)

Prevents action of factors VIII - XII and production of thrombin/fibrin.

Used in renal insufficiency

Warfarin

Inhibits hepatic production of factors II, VII, IX and X

questions.text: When performing the test on a patient as shown in the image, you noticed that there was tenderness and resistance on flexion. What is this finding known as?
questions.solution:
The given findings can be seen in a patient with DVT and this is known as Homan’s sign i.e. calf tenderness and resistance on forced ankle dorsiflexion.

Moses Sign - calf tenderness on squeezing the calf from sides.

Lowenberg’s sign- pain when blood pressure cuff placed on the calf is inflated to 80 mm of Hg

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman who is in the third trimester of pregnancy started to experience pain in her left leg. She also noticed that her left leg was turning pale and edematous as given in the image below. What is the cause of this condition?

choices.text: Femoral vein thrombosis and lymphatic obstruction
Due to pressure exerted by uterus on the iliac veins

questions.solution:
The patient is having phlegmasia alba dolens also known milk leg or white leg. It is due to ileofemoral deep vein thrombosis.

It is usually seen in pregnant women and in individuals at risk of developing deep vein thrombosis. They typically present with painful, oedematous, and pale lower limb that blanches to touch. The lack of cyanosis differentiates this entity from phlegmasia cerulea dolens.

In phlegmasia alba dolens, the thrombosis involves only major deep venous channels of the extremity, thus sparing collateral veins. The venous drainage is decreased but still present.

In phlegmasia cerulea dolens, the thrombosis extends to collateral veins, resulting in severe venous congestion with massive fluid sequestration and more significant edema.

Both phlegmasia cerulea dolens and phlegmasia alba dolens results from acute massive deep vein thrombosis and can be complicated by venous gangrene.

Edema of pregnancy does not present with pain in the lower limbs but edema due to pressure exerted by the gravid uterus on the iliac veins.

questions.text: You are tasked with giving post-operative care to a patient who just underwent open abdominal surgery. Which of the following is the most effective treatment to prevent the patient from developing deep vein thrombosis?
questions.solution:
Heparin, especially low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) is more effective for prophylaxis of DVT in patients who have undergone major surgeries where early ambulation is not possible. 

The choice of prophylaxis depends on the type of surgery, trauma, and duration of postoperative immobilisation. Major trauma, abdominal and orthopaedic surgeries warrant a longer duration of postoperative immobilisation. So, the pharmacological method is preferred in these situations.

Mechanical methods are advised in patients who are expected to be up and walking within 24 to 48 hours such as after minor trauma. The simplest method is for the patient to ambulate. The activation of the calf pump mechanism is an effective means of prophylaxis.

Additionally, compression stockings are advised. It can reduce the risk of DVT by exerting graduated pressure on the leg, with the pressure being greatest at the ankle.

Advantages of LMWH over unfractionated heparin: 

  • LMWH has a longer plasma half-life and significantly higher bioavailability.
  • The consistent bioavail­ability and clearance of LMWH do not require monitoring of aPTT or anti-factor Xa activity.
  • Dosing is merely based on the patient’s weight.
  • There is a more predictable anticoagulant response than with unfractionated heparin.

LMWH inhibits factor Xa and not IIa activity, with the ratio of anti-factor Xa to anti-factor IIa activity ranging from 1:1 to 4:1.

Related Pearl: Prophylaxis for DVT

Mechanical prophylaxis
Early ambulation

Acts by activating the calf pump mechanism
Pneumatic compression stocking

Prevents stasis by periodically compressing the calves
Pharmacological prophylaxis

Low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) - Enoxaparin

Fondaparinux

 Prevent thrombus formation by inhibiting factor Xa

Apixaban

Rivaroxaban 

  Oral factor Xa inhibitors

Unfractionated heparin (UFH)

Prevents action of factors VIII - XII and production of thrombin/fibrin.

Used in renal insufficiency

Warfarin

Inhibits hepatic production of factors II, VII, IX and X

questions.text: All of the following are risk factors for developing varicose veins, except?
questions.solution:
Superficial venous thrombosis is not a risk factor for developing varicose veins because the deep venous system is not affected and there is no increased stasis of blood.  

Varicose veins are defined as dilated, usually tortuous, subcutaneous veins >3 mm in diameter measured in the upright position with demonstrable reflux.

Important risk factors for varicose veins are:

  • Sex – Females > Males
  • Age – increases with age
  • Pregnancy (especially multiparity)
  • Family history
  • Body mass and height: Increasing BMI (obesity) and height are associated with a high prevalence of varicose veins.

There is inconclusive evidence regarding the increased prevalence of varicose veins in smokers, patients who suffer constipation, and occupations that involve prolonged standing.

Primary varicose veins are due to genetic or developmental defects in the vein wall that causes diminished elasticity and valvular incompetence. 

Secondary varicose veins arise from destruction or dysfunction of valves caused by trauma, DVT, AV fistula, non-traumatic proximal venous obstruction (pregnancy, pelvic tumor).

questions.text: A truck driver presents with dilated, tortuous veins of 4 mm in the foot. What is the stage of clinical classification according to CEAP(Clinical-etiology-anatomy-pathophysiology for chronic venous disorders)?
questions.solution:
Dilated tortuous veins of 4 mm indicate varicose veins, so the stage is C2.

Related Pearl: CEAP Classification of Chronic Lower Extremity Venous Disease

CEAP (Clinical-Etiology-Anatomy-Pathophysiology)

Clinical classification (C)*

C0

No visible or palpable signs of venous disease

C1

Telangiectases or reticular veins

C2

C2r

Varicose veins

Recurrent varicose veins

C3

Edema

C4

Changes in skin and subcutaneous tissue secondary

to chronic venous disease

C4a-Pigmentation or eczema

C4b-Lipodermatosclerosis or atrophie blanche

C4c-Corona phlebectatica

C5

Healed ulcer

C6

C6r

Active ulcer

Recurrent active venous ulcer

S

With symptoms attributable to venous disease

A

Absence of symptoms attributable to venous disease

Etiological classification (E)

Ec

Congenital (Klippel-Trenaunay syndrome)

Ep

Primary

Es

Secondary (postthrombotic syndrome, trauma)

Esi

Secondary (intravenous)

Ese

Secondary (extravenous)

Ec

Congenital

En

No venous cause identified

Anatomic classification (A)

As

Superficial

Ad

Deep

Ap

Perforator

An

No venous location identified

Patho-physiologic classification (P)

Pr

Reflux

Po

Obstruction, thrombosis

Pr,o

Reflux and obstruction

Pn

No venous pathophysiology identified

Note:

  • The descriptor A (asymptomatic) or S (symptomatic) is placed after the C clinical class.
  • Telengiactesia refers to tiny intradermal venules <1 mm in diameter.
  • Reticular veins refer to small dilated subdermal blue veins of 1 to 2.9 mm
  • Varicose veins refer to dilated tortuous veins >3 mm in diameter

questions.text: A 42-year-old  daily wage laborer comes to you with discoloration of her legs. She was diagnosed with varicose veins 5 years ago which was left untreated. Identify the feature given in the picture.
questions.solution:
Atrophia blanche is localised white atrophic skin frequently surrounded by dilated capillaries and hyperpigmentation, usually seen around the ankles. This is a sign of chronic venous disease.

Lipodermatosclerosis is changes in the skin of the lower legs due to chronic venous insufficiency. It is a form of panniculitis (inflammation of the layer of fat under the skin). There is swelling and a tapering of the legs above the ankles, leading to 'inverted champagne bottle' appearance.

 

Corona phlebectatica are fan-shaped patterns of small intradermal veins on the medial or lateral aspects of the ankle or foot. It is also called ankle flare or malleolar flare. It is an early sign of advanced venous disease.

Related Pearl: CEAP Classification of Chronic Lower Extremity Venous Disease

CEAP (Clinical-Etiology-Anatomy-Pathophysiology)

Clinical classification (C)*

C0

No visible or palpable signs of venous disease

C1

Telangiectases or reticular veins

C2

C2r

Varicose veins

Recurrent varicose veins

C3

Edema

C4

Changes in skin and subcutaneous tissue secondary

to chronic venous disease

C4a-Pigmentation or eczema

C4b-Lipodermatosclerosis or atrophie blanche

C4c-Corona phlebectatica

C5

Healed ulcer

C6

C6r

Active ulcer

Recurrent active venous ulcer

S

With symptoms attributable to venous disease

A

Absence of symptoms attributable to venous disease

Etiological classification (E)

Ec

Congenital (Klippel-Trenaunay syndrome)

Ep

Primary

Es

Secondary (postthrombotic syndrome, trauma)

Esi

Secondary (intravenous)

Ese

Secondary (extravenous)

Ec

En

Anatomic classification (A)

As

Ap

Patho-physiologic classification (P)

Pr

Reflux

Po

Obstruction, thrombosis

Pr,o

Pn

No venous pathophysiology identified

Note:

  • The descriptor A (asymptomatic) or S (symptomatic) is placed after the C clinical class.
  • Telengiactesia refers to tiny intradermal venules <1 mm in diameter.
  • Reticular veins refer to small dilated subdermal blue veins of 1 to 2.9 mm
  • Varicose veins refer to dilated tortuous veins >3 mm in diameter

questions.text: A bus conductor was diagnosed with varicose veins. On examination, skin eczema and lipodermatosclerosis were noted. According to the CEAP classification system, He would be classified as
questions.solution:
According to CEAP classification, varicose veins with skin eczema and lipodermatosclerosis come under the clinical class of C4.

The clinical class of C4 under CEAP includes changes in skin and subcutaneous tissue secondary to chronic venous disease. It is further classified as,

  • C4a- pigmentation or eczema
  • C4b- lipodermatosclerosis or atrophie blanche
  • C4c- corona phlebectatica

Recent 2020 update on the CEAP system:

  • C2r for recurrent varicose veins
  • C4c for Corona phlebectatica
  • C6r for recurrent active venous ulcer.

Related Pearl: CEAP Classification of Chronic Lower Extremity Venous Disease

CEAP (Clinical-Etiology-Anatomy-Pathophysiology)

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding Klippel-Trenaunay syndrome?

choices.text: Surgery is indicated in all cases
Increased risk of deep vein thrombosis

questions.solution:
All patients with Klippel–Trenaunay syndrome should be treated conservatively with elastic compression. A surgical intervention is only indicated for affected large superficial veins provided the underlying deep system is normal and demonstrates only mild-to-moderate reflux.

Klippel-Trenaunay syndrome is a sporadic nonhereditary mesodermal abnormality that usually affects a single lower limb with deep veins which have hypoplastic or aplastic segments. It is characterized by a triad of:

  • Haemangioma presenting as nevus flammeus (port-wine stain)
  • Varicose veins
  • Soft tissue and bone hypertrophy 

Venous stripping, ligation, excision, or sclerotherapy are done in suitable cases. Low molecular weight heparin should be given to all patients undergoing surgical procedures as this syndrome is associated with an increased risk of venous thromboembolism.

questions.text: A patient presents to you with dilated, tortuous veins of the legs. Which is the best investigation to perform that will confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Duplex ultrasound is the best investigation to confirm varicose veins.

Duplex ultrasound gives information about the presence of blood flow in the studied vessels such as its speed, direction and turbulence alongwith image of surrounding tissues.

The aim of the duplex scan in patients with varicose veins is to establish:

  • If saphenous junctions are incompetent and the extent of reflux in the saphenous veins and their diameters.
  • Number, location, and diameter of incompetent perforating veins
  • Source of all superficial varices 
  • Competence and evidence of previous venous thrombosis in the deep venous system.

Doppler study only gives information about the presence of blood flow in the studied vessels such as its speed, direction, and turbulence, not the surrounding tissue.

Very rarely if pelvic and iliac veins are involved then CT or MR venography might be opted for, when duplex ultrasound fails to visualise properly.

questions.text: Which vessel is not involved in the formation of mickey mouse sign that is seen while performing a duplex ultrasound?
questions.solution:
Mickey mouse sign is seen in transverse B mode image of duplex ultrasound formed by:

  • Common Femoral Vein (CFV)
  • Common Femoral Artery (CFA)
  • Greater Saphenous Vein (GSV) at the Saphenofemoral junction (SFJ).

It represents the normal anatomy of the femoral vessels as seen in a duplex ultrasound.

questions.text: A duplex ultrasound was done on a patient with varicose veins. It revealed incompetence of the perforator connecting the great saphenous vein to the superficial femoral vein. What is this perforator known as?
questions.solution:
Dodd’s perforator connects the great saphenous vein to the superficial femoral veins. It is also known as ‘above knee’ perforator and is seen at the inferior ⅓ of the thigh. 

Perforating veins connect the superficial venous system to the deep venous system by penetrating the fascial layers of the lower extremity. Although the total number of perforator veins is variable, up to 100 have been documented.

Named perforators:

  • Adductor Canal (thigh) – Hunter's perforator
  • Above Knee – Dodd's  perforator
  • Below Knee – Boyd's perforator
  • Medial Calf – Cockett I, II, and III perforator
  • Ankle - May or Kustner perforator

questions.text: Presence of which of the following would make a patient with varicose veins unsuitable for sclerotherapy?

choices.text: Recurrence of varicose veins after ligation and stripping surgery

questions.solution:
Deep vein thrombosis is a contraindication for sclerotherapy in varicose veins.

This is because, in patients with DVT, the superficial veins are the only valved venous pathway carrying blood back to the heart, and excising them in the presence of deep venous thrombosis will only aggravate the condition.

questions.text: Which sclerosant is most commonly used when performing sclerotherapy for varicose veins?
questions.solution:
The most commonly used sclerosant is sodium tetradecyl sulfate.

In injection sclerotherapy a detergent is injected directly into the superficial veins. The detergent destroys the lipid membranes of endothelial cells causing them to shed, leading to thrombosis, fibrosis and obliteration (sclerosis).

Injection sclerotherapy alone can be successful in varicose veins <3 mm in diameter and in telangiectatic vessels.

Complications of sclerotherapy: 

  • Allergic reaction, 
  • Local hyperpigmentation
  • Thrombophlebitis
  • DVT
  • Skin necrosis

Patients with symptomatic GSV or SSV reflux may be treated with endovenous ablation techniques or surgical removal of the affected vein.

Saphenous vein ligation and stripping is preferred therapy for patients with GSVs of very large diameter (>2 cm).

Types of sclerosants:

Detergents

  • Sodium tetradecyl sulfate
  • Polidocanol
  • Sodium morrhuate
  • Ethanolamine oleate

Osmotic agents

  • Hypertonic saline

Chemical irritants

  • Chromated glycerin
  • Polyiodinated iodine 
  • Alcoholic solution of zein
  • Bleomycin

Tessari method 

  • Widely used method to prepare foam for sclerotherapy
  • Sclerosant : Air ratio taken is 1:3 or 1:4.

questions.text: Which of the following is done in Trendelenburg operation?

choices.text: Stripping of the superficial varicose vein
Ligation of small tributaries at the distal end of superficial varicose vein

questions.solution:
Saphenofemoral flush ligation is done in Trendelenburg’s procedure. 

The great saphenous vein is stripped and tied close to the common femoral vein at the saphenofemoral junction so that there aren’t any branches left that lead to recurrences.

Procedure:

An oblique groin incision is made at the level of and lateral to the pubic tubercle. The great saphenous vein is identified and dissected to the saphenofemoral junction.

Six great saphenous vein tributaries are normally encountered close to the saphenofemoral junction: 

  1. The superficial inferior epigastric vein and superficial circumflex iliac vein laterally
  2. The deep and superficial external pudendal veins medially
  3. More distally the anterolateral and posteromedial thigh veins

A flush saphenofemoral junction ligation is then performed and the great saphenous vein retrogradely stripped to the knee. Flush ligation is when the great saphenous vein is stripped and tied close to the common femoral vein at the saphenofemoral junction so that there aren’t any tributaries that lead to recurrences.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding complications of varicose vein surgery is false?

choices.text: Injury to the lymphatic system can cause secondary lymphoedema
Saphenous nerve injury causes loss of sensation in the medial aspect of the leg
The sural nerve is in danger during stripping of the great saphenous vein

questions.solution:
The sural nerve accompanies the short saphenous vein laterally along its course and supplies cutaneous sensation to the lateral malleolar region. Thus it is more prone to injury during stripping of the short saphenous vein, not the great saphenous vein.

The saphenous nerve accompanies the great saphenous vein medially from the ankle to the level of the knee and supplies cutaneous sensation to the medial leg and ankle. Thus it is more prone to injury during stripping of the great saphenous vein.

Surgery for the varicose veins extraction may trigger injury of the lymph vessels and may lead to secondary lymphedema.

Injury and inflammation to the venous system during varicose vein surgery can cause slowing and stasis of blood flow in the lower limb, making them prone to develop deep vein thrombosis postoperatively.

questions.text: In patients with chronic venous insufficiency, where are venous ulcers most likely to develop?
questions.solution:
Venous ulcers due to chronic venous insufficiency are most commonly seen in the lower ⅓ of the leg and foot. They usually lie just proximal to the medial or lateral malleolus.

Venous ulcers are accompanied by lipodermatosclerosis and hemosiderosis. 

Feature  Venous ulcer  Arterial ulcer
Predisposing factors

Varicose veins

Previous DVT

Recurrent superficial thrombophlebitis

Peripheral arterial disease

Diabetes

Smoking

Hypertension
Location Lower 1/3 of leg 'gaiters area'

Lateral malleolus and tibial aspect of leg

Toes and feet
Ulcer characteristics

Shallow and flat margins

Exudate with slough and granulation tissue at base of wound

Punched out, deep, and irregular in shape

Necrotic and unhealthy tissue at base of wound

 
Appearance of  the lower limb

Lipodermatosclerosis

Atrophie blanche

Limb oedema

Normal capillary refill time

Pale, shiny skin

Absent or weak peripheral pulses

Delayed capillary refill time

questions.text: A 61-year-old man presented with a recurrent, tender, erythematous rash on the medial aspect of the right forearm and lower limb as shown in the image. He was diagnosed with pancreatic adenocarcinoma 1 year ago.  Blood investigations showed normal eosinophil counts and no signs of infections. What is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Secondary to repeated cannulation of vein

questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is migratory thrombophlebitis.

It is a paraneoplastic syndrome that is also known as Trousseau’s syndrome or Trousseau's sign of malignancy. It is characterised by recurrent episodes of localised thrombosis of the superficial veins of limbs. It can lead to tender and erythematous rashes.

Migratory thrombophlebitis is seen in: 

  • Pancreatic cancer (most common)
  • Lung cancer
  • Gastrointestinal cancer
  • Ovarian cancer
  • Prostate cancer
  • Lymphoma

Note: Trousseau’s sign is seen in hypocalcemia where there is an involuntary contraction of the muscles of the hand and wrist when a blood pressure cuff is placed on the arm and inflated to 20mm of Hg above systolic blood pressure.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient with sudden onset pain, cyanosis, and edema of the left upper limb. Doppler ultrasound revealed thrombosis of the left subclavian vein. Which of the following is false regarding this condition?

choices.text: Can be caused by indwelling venous catheters
Primary axillary vein thrombosis is seen in hypercoagulable states
May occur following excessive arm exercise

questions.solution:
The patient has axillary-subclavian vein thrombosis. Hypercoagulable states lead to secondary axillary vein thrombosis.

Axillary-subclavian vein thrombosis (ASVT) is of 2 types.

Primary ASVT occurs as a result of compression of the subclavian vein in the costoclavicular space by repeated contraction of muscles that surround the thoracic outlet. There is repeated compression and traumatization to the vein. This leads to the formation of clots. It is also known as:

  • Paget-Schrotter Syndrome 
  • Venous thoracic outlet syndrome
  • Effort thrombosis

Secondary ASVT occurs due to venous injury by indwelling central venous catheters, external trauma or pacemaker wires. It is also seen in hypercoagulable states.

Symptoms and signs include pain, edema, and cyanosis of the upper extremity. Significant superficial venous distension can be seen in arm, forearm, shoulder and anterior chest wall.

Doppler study is the investigation of choice. Anticoagulation is initiated once ASVT is diagnosed to prevent pulmonary embolism.In severe cases, thrombolytic therapy is done using tissue plasminogen activator (rtPA) or streptokinase.

Adjuvant procedures following thrombolytic therapy may include balloon angioplasty for residual venous narrowing and cervical or first rib resection for thoracic outlet abnormalities.

questions.text: Identify the device given below.
questions.solution:
The given image shows a chemoport.

Chemoports are implantable venous access devices used to facilitate chemotherapy administration.

Internal jugular veins and subclavian veins are the commonly used access veins for port placement. These devices are usually retained for a period of 1 to 2 years or more after which the device is explanted.

questions.text: Which of the following vessel is affected in May-Thurner syndrome?
questions.solution:
May-Thurner syndrome refers to iliofemoral venous thrombosis.

At the site where the right iliac artery crosses over the left iliac vein, the left iliac vein may become chronically narrowed predisposing to iliofemoral venous thrombosis.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman with a history of varicose vein, presented with a painless lesion on her left leg for the past 1 month. On examination, an ulcer of size 5 ✕ 5 cm with an irregular margin and sloping edge was found on the medial malleolus of the left leg. All the following can be used to manage this patient except?

choices.text: Surgical excision and pinch mesh grafting

questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis, in this case, is a venous ulcer secondary to the varicose vein. Revascularization is not a part of the management of venous ulcers. 
Venous ulcers are due to chronic venous insufficiency and are particularly seen in the area between the muscles of the calf and ankle. It has a sloping edge and the floor contains granulation tissue covered by slough and exudate. Marjolin’s ulcer is a type of squamous cell carcinoma seen in chronic long-standing venous ulcers.

Management of venous ulcers:

  • Bisgaard's regimen
    • Education
    • Elevation of the affected limb to reduce the edema
    • Elastic compression stockings - The ideal interface pressure in venous ulceration is 35-40 mmHg.
    • Evaluation
  • 4 layer bandaging system comprising of:
    • Orthopedic wool
    • Cotton crepe
    • Elastic bandage - first compressive layer
    • Cohesive bandage - second compressive layer
  • Antibiotics are given only if the wound is infected.
  • Regular dressing.
  • Medical management by oral pentoxifylline is considered which helps in reducing the viscosity and improving circulation. 
  •  Surgery - Ulcer excision with pinch mesh grafting has a good outcome and helps in preventing recurrence.

questions.text: A 40-year-old hairdresser presented with complaints of swelling, throbbing pain, and heaviness in her left leg for the past 1 year. A duplex scan done showed great saphenous vein incompetence. Which of the following is the treatment of choice?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of varicose veins and the treatment of choice in this patient is endothermal ablation.
Management of varicose veins

1. Great saphenous vein (GSV) and saphenofemoral incompetence (SFJ) 

  • Endothermal ablation - It is the gold standard method. It includes:
    • Endovenous laser ablation (EVLA)
    • Radiofrequency ablation (RFA.
  • Trendelenburg procedure ± stripping  - Flush ligation of SFJ and ligation of 6 tributaries.

2. Short saphenous vein (SSJ) and saphenopopliteal incompetence (SPJ). 

  • Flush ligation of SPJ. No stripping is done to prevent nerve injury
  • EVLA or RFA.

3. Perforator incompetence

  • Dodd and Crockett surgery - Multiple subfacial ligations.
  • Subfascial endoscopic perforator surgery (SEPS)
  • EVLA or RFA

New treatment modalities

  • Foam sclerotherapy 
  • Endovenous glue therapy
  • TriVex - Transilluminated powered phlebectomy

questions.text: A 55-year-old locomotive operator presents with complaints of worm-like swelling over his right leg. During clinical examination, a Brodie Trendelenburg test is performed. Which of the following statements is false regarding the test?

choices.text: A tourniquet can be used for occluding the saphenofemoral junction
Rapid filling  from above indicates saphenofemoral incompetence
Gradual filling  from below upwards indicates saphenopopliteal incompetence
Positive Brodie Trendelenburg test indicates a need for surgery

questions.solution:
The gradual filling of veins from below upwards indicates the perforator incompetence. Brodie Trendelenberg test is performed to test for the incompetence of the saphenofemoral valve and the communicating system.

1. Trendelenburg’s test - Lay the patient down and elevate the leg. Empty the vessels and tie a tourniquet below the SFJ. Ask the patient to stand up:

  • Trendelenburg’s test part ll - Here the tourniquet is not released. A gradual filling from below to upwards indicates perforator incompetence.
  • Trendelenburg’s test part l - Here the tourniquet is released. A rapid filling from above shows the saphenofemoral incompetence.

2. Morrisey’s cough impulse: the patient is asked to cough. A cough impulse at the saphenofemoral junction indicates SFJ incompetence.

3. Schwartz test: If a thrill is felt at SFJ on tapping over the incompetent vein, indicates SFJ incompetence.

4. Modified Perthes test: A tourniquet is tied below SFJ and the patient is asked to walk. An increase in pain and prominence of dilated veins indicate DVT.

5. Fegan’s method - Mark the places of excessive bulges within the varicosities. Ask the patient to lie down and empty the varicose vessels. Palpate along the marked area to look for gaps and pits in the deep fascia, which indicates perforator incompetence.
